docs.lead_paragraph: Based on their baby pictures, five New Mexico children would appear to be related. But instead, these babies were connected only by their birth defects and by sharing a genetic disorder that might have first occurred here about 400 years ago, when Spanish settlers first arrived. Now, a New Mexico doctor is piecing together the clues of this mysterious and newly detected ailment among a few families, and a local genealogist is trying to find a possible historical connection.

headline.main: 5 Birth-Defect Cases Tell a Centuries-Old Tale

docs.abstract: Dr Carol Clericuzio, pediatric clinical geneticist at University of New Mexico, is studying five separate known cases of yet unnamed genetic disorder possibly linked to Spanish settlers migrating to area 400 years ago; disease is believed to be founder effect and to have been silently carried for generations; only Nicole Armijo, age 7, is alive, other four children having died before they were three years old; Clericuzio hopes to identify gene that causes disorder; symptoms include dwarfism, small kidneys and recessed eyes; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Both the fatality rate of motorcycle riders and the actual number of deaths have risen sharply in the last five years and hit their highest levels in more than a decade, traffic safety officials said today. Regulators cannot say precisely what has led to the reversal because, for lack of financing, no comprehensive study of motorcycle deaths has been done since the 1970's.

headline.main: Traffic Safety Officials See Sharp Rise in Motorcycle Fatalities

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Appointee for Baghdad Vows to Restore Services Jay Garner, a retired American lieutenant general and the man the Bush administration appointed to run Iraq, arrived in Baghdad to a muted reception, promising to restore services as fast as possible and not to overstay his welcome. A1
